title: EDI
text:
I am deeply committed to creating and ensuring an equitable, diverse, and inclusive environment for all students, trainees, and collaborators in the research group. Below are some of the ways I aim to increase and adopt EDI values within this research group:

I strongly encourage and support student and trainee applications from underrepresented and equity-deserving groups for all positions, including BIPOC, persons with disabilities, women, and 2SLGBTQ+.
I document and ensure equitable access to training, development, and mentoring opportunities for all students and trainees.
I promote and encourage EDI-related training opportunities for all team members (e.g., addressing and reducing unconscious bias, microaggressions, anti-racism).
I aim to foster proactive inclusion of all team members by promoting a safe, respectful, and supportive work environment that is responsive to diverse situations, needs, and accommodations.
I continuously strive to improve my understanding of and actions within the research group aimed at addressing and mitigating systemic academic and research barriers faced by those from different underrepresented groups.

title: Contact
text:
If you are a prospective undergraduate student, graduate student, or post-doctoral fellow interested in this research group and any related opportunities, please feel free to contact Dr. Young via email with a copy of your CV and some information about your background and research interests. Contact details are as follows:
School of Occupational and Public Health
Toronto Metropolitan University
288 Church Street, DCC 320 Toronto, ON M5B 2K3
Tel: +1 416-979-5000 Ext. 557614
Email: iyoung@torontomu.ca
Campus directions and map: https://www.torontomu.ca/maps/

title: People
text:
Mastodon
  
  
    
     Github
  

      
Dr. Ian Young is an Associate Professor in the School of Occupational and Public Health, Toronto Metropolitan University. He is also a member of the Yeates School of Graduate Studies and supervises students in the MSc in Occupational and Public Health and MASc/PhD Environmental Applied Science and Management programs. He is a wrangler of one toddler, husband, and in his spare time loves to run, exercise, cook, read sci-fi/fantasy books, play board games, and travel.



BASc in Public Health and Safety, Toronto Metropolitan University, 2007
PhD in Epidemiology, University of Guelph, 2010





Associate Professor, Toronto Metropolitan University, Since 2021
Assistant Professor, Toronto Metropolitan University, 2016 - 2020
Food Safety Expert, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 2015
Epidemiologist, Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC), 2013 - 2014
Post-Doctoral Fellow, University of Guelph & PHAC, 2011 - 2013

title: KTT
text: A series of infographics has been developed to highlight the results of several research studies in the group. Click on the images below to access and download a copy.

title: KTT
text:
Selected News / Media Stories
Dec. 12, 2022. Dr. Young appeared on Episode 2 of the TMU Environmental Applied Science and Management Program “The Climate” podcast to talk about his background, research, and advice for future students and trainees.
July 17, 2022. Dr. Young was quoted and interviewed in a Triathlete Magazine article about brain-eating amoebas.
July 14, 2022. Dr. Young was quoted and interviewed in a Triathlete Magazine article about our published study on determinants of swimming pool bather hygienic behaviours.
June 1, 2022. Dr. Young’s Ontario Early Career Researcher Award was featured in this Toronto Metropolitan University article.
May 31, 2022. Dr. Young was interviewed on live TV in this Breakfast Television segment about beach water quality.
Nov, 17, 2021. Dr. Young and Dr. Sekercioglu’s funded study on improving food safety in ready-to-eat meat processing plants in Ontario was profiled by Faculty of Community Services.
Jul. 19, 2021: Dr. Young was quoted and interviewed for the Climate Atlas of Canada’s section on “waterborne disease and climate change”.
